summary: Rocky Balboa (Sylvester Stallone), a small-time boxer from working-class Philadelphia, is arbitrarily chosen to take on the reigning world heavyweight champion, Apollo Creed (Carl Weathers), when the undefeated fighter's scheduled opponent is injured. While training with feisty former bantamweight contender Mickey Goldmill (Burgess Meredith), Rocky tentatively begins a relationship with Adrian (Talia Shire), the wallflower sister of his meat-packer pal Paulie (Burt Young).

reviews.content: The first film in this saga is a little confusing in dialogues and narrative, but I like the performance of the characters. "Rocky," directed by John G. Avildsen and written by and starring Sylvester Stallone, is an American sports drama film released in 1976. The film follows the story of Rocky Balboa, a down-on-his-luck boxer from Philadelphia, who is given the opportunity of a lifetime to fight the heavyweight champion of the world, Apollo Creed.

The movie's main strength is its captivating story and well-written characters, particularly Rocky. Stallone's portrayal of Rocky is nothing short of brilliant, and his performance earned him an Academy Award nomination for Best Actor. Rocky is a complex character who is both tough and vulnerable, and audiences cannot help but root for him as he struggles to make something of himself in the world of boxing.

The supporting cast also gives outstanding performances, with Talia Shire as Adrian, Rocky's love interest, and Burgess Meredith as Mickey, Rocky's gruff but caring trainer, standing out in particular. The chemistry between Rocky and Adrian is sweet and genuine, and their love story is an integral part of the film's emotional impact.

The film's cinematography and editing are also noteworthy. The iconic training montage sequence set to Bill Conti's stirring "Gonna Fly Now" theme is an indelible part of cinematic history, and the fight scenes are filmed with intensity and realism that are a testament to the filmmakers' dedication to accuracy.

Overall, "Rocky" is a timeless classic that stands the test of time. It's a movie that is not just about boxing, but about the human spirit and the ability to overcome seemingly insurmountable odds. It's a movie that will inspire and move viewers, and its impact on pop culture cannot be overstated.

The film is not just about boxing, but it's a character-driven story that explores themes of self-discovery, redemption, and the power of determination. Stallone's portrayal of Rocky is simply outstanding, and he brings a depth and vulnerability to the character that makes him so relatable and endearing. From his awkward attempts at wooing Adrian to his heart-wrenching conversations with his coach Mickey, Stallone's performance is nothing short of incredible.

The supporting cast is also impressive, with Talia Shire giving a nuanced performance as Adrian, Rocky's shy love interest, and Burgess Meredith stealing the show as Mickey, Rocky's tough-talking coach. The chemistry between the characters is palpable, and their relationships are beautifully developed over the course of the film.

The boxing scenes are also expertly crafted, with Avildsen using close-ups and slow-motion shots to capture the raw emotion and intensity of the fights. The climactic bout between Rocky and Apollo Creed is a true masterpiece, with both actors giving it their all and making every punch count.

Overall, "Rocky" is an inspiring and uplifting film that celebrates the human spirit and reminds us of the power of perseverance. It's a must-see for anyone who loves sports films, character-driven dramas, or just great cinema in general.

This being Sylvester Stallone's first big film, his acting is excusable, however I feel that the lack of acting skill adds to the character of Rocky, his awkward delivery of lines and lack of confidence adds to the character and makes it more realistic. The storyline, while extremely unlikely is still probable is is not an absurd series of events like the story's of the cinema today.

One of my biggest highlights of the film is the ending. It was somewhat unpredictable and in my opinion one of the best endings in the whole franchise. 

"Rocky" provides some of the most iconic scenes in cinema history as well as one of the most recognisable soundtracks of all time.

Rocky is an inspiring story about an ordinary man who takes advantage of a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity.

I do have to say, the movie has a rocky beginning, as the dialogue is pretty clunky and awkward at times. But after about twenty minutes, the movie really gets into its groove and had me locked in till the end. My favorite aspect of this film is the humanity it has; it takes a look at a big and intimidating fighter in Rocky and explores his emotions and insecurities. My favorite scene is when he lays in bed next to Adrian with the sudden realization that he cannot win this fight. It was an incredibly vulnerable moment for him and worked really well.

As I said before, the dialogue is very inconsistent, especially in the scene at Rocky's house with Adrian. It was very unsettling to watch because she is written as if she does not want to be there, but then the next second she is in love with him. It was very weird and creepy. On the other hand, in some scenes, the dialogue is written very well, which lends itself to boosting the actors' performances. But when it is off, the acting on display is negatively affected. Despite that, this movie gets a lot more right than it does wrong in the script department.

Technically, this film excels. The score is fantastic, with one of the most iconic songs in cinematic history. The cinematography is top-notch, with some incredible shots in the city and very creative angles used during the training sequences. 

Overall, this film lived up to every ounce of hype it had behind it, and I thoroughly enjoyed every second spent with these characters.

This is one of the best and most transformative films of all time.   Written and starring Sylvester Stallone as the underdog fighter given the chance of a lifetime it succeeds in every area. The boxing choreography was very engaging.  The soundtrack is sharp.   The joy of Rocky is that the movie being made, like the movie's substance, is an underdog story of epic proportions.   The movie spawned an entire franchise and, while, Quentin Tarantino calls Rocky II the best movie of the franchise there is no substitute for the original in my book.  This one holds up.

The seventies was the best era for sports movies.  You've got Bad News Bears, North Dallas Forty, Brian's Song, the Longest Yard, Bang the Drum Slowly, Breaking Away; The Greatest; Fat City, Le Mans, Pumping Iron; and then the list goes on....   Those just aren't some of the best sports movies ever made; those are some of the best movies made, period!  Topping that list was Rocky.  A gritty; new-wave; 70s ciname verite type movie; almost a documentary; about a part time hood; a loser from the streets of Philadelphia; Rocky Balboa; that no one likes;  who is handpicked from the publicity firm of Apollo Creed; the current reigning champion; (who is supposed to represent a cocky Mohammed Ali); to fight him in a big, hyped up celebrity match.  And so the bulk of the movie feels like a Cinderella Story.  (The sports announcers even call it a Cinderella Story in the movie itself!). Rocky is lifted up from obscurity; and anointed by the press as the new David who will slay Goliath.  And David and Goliath stories aren't new for sports movies.  Heck Casey at the Bat was a similar David and Goliath, underdog-coming-from-behind type story; and it infact had a similarly shocking, downbeat ending; and that poem was written by Ernest Thayer in 1888!  So none of this is new.  But Stallone; (who refused to let anyone else star in Rocky; even after his buddy Henry Winkler had it optioned by ABC in 75); gives this story such intensity and veracity.  And the plot; where Rocky knows he's out of his league; but he's going to put it all on the line to go the distance.  He knows he's going to lose.  But he's going to stay alive for 15 rounds; and not get knocked out.  He'll do anything literally to go the distance.  Leading to the stunning ending where he's being pummeled and punished by Apollo, but, to everyone's surprise, he does not give up.  What a heartbreaking and inspiring ending! That's what sets this Rocky apart.  The goal is not to win; the goal is to never give up; very different from the other movies; it's got that epic; mythological Sisyphus pushing the Rock up the hill against all odds feeling! That paired with his iconic training scene; jogging through the streets of Philadelphia at the dawn; running up the stairway at the Philadelphia Museum of Art like a wild bull unleashed in Spain, as Bill Conti's thunderous sports anthem "Gonna Fly Now" booms viscerally in the background; and then turning; to the dawn; and the blazing sunrise; as he lifts his arms triumphantly in the air; this is a pure adrenaline rush few other movies can deliver!  Raging Bull might be more artfully made; and Million Dollar Baby might be more tragic; but Rocky has them all beat in terms of pure, raw inspiration.

I could see how this could be viewed as a 'living the American dream' type watch, or perhaps moreso an 'underdog' tale. Its quite a solid watch. Given im not a particular fan of sports, especially boxing, I wasn't expecting a great deal of this but I reckon I enjoyed it more than I perhaps imagined I might because the majority of the film isn't set in the ring, as it were and instead it concentrated on Rocky's life outside the ring, his clearly low-ish standing and it shows how he did what he could to try and raise himself above that.

Rocky is the movie that, at the time, was the definitive boxing movie, and in many ways still is. It takes an everyman fighter from Philly Rocky Balboa, someone the audience can connect with, and uts him in the biggest spotlight-a title match with the Heavyweight champ Apollo Creed. It follows Rocky as he trains for his fight, while leaving plenty of room for character development, relationships, and romance. Sylvester Stallone does a great job in both acting in the title role and writing the script, and the supporting cast is also excellent. The score is one of the best in cinema history, especially when played behind the ionic Rocky training sequence. Rocky also has tons of iconic imagery and diolague, too. And the final fight is also thrilling, even if it has a somewhat predictable ending.  There are some issues, though. There are only two boxing fights in the whole movie, the very beginning and very end. And the rest of the movie, though it has some fun moments, feels slow and dragged-on at times. Overall, Rocky is the movie that kickstarted a franchise, and while it had some low moments, the high ones soared.

This about a bum from Philadelphia given a chance of a lifetime to fight the heavyweight champion of the world, Apollo Creed. Rocky Balboa is a underdog from Philly who goes through a character arc of learning to take responsibility for his life, don't make excuses, and keep trying. During his time training, he gets in a relationship with the shy Adrian, gains a friendship with Paulie (brother of Adrian), and gets a father figure in Micky who trains Rocky.  This movie has a remarkable soundtrack from Bill Conti (songs like Gonna Fly Now, Philadelphia Morning, Going the Distance). This movie, even though it's a bit boring in parts, carries remarkable heart and life lessons. The heart in this movie is beyond excellent, and the care put into it is outstanding. The morals of this movie to never stop trying, and winning isn't anything reigns true to this day.

There isn't much that hasn't been said about this film in the last forty-four years. From the story, to the characters to the score to the moral message. It all blends together to produce a wholesome, inspiring film. One which dares to say that sometimes going the distance and refusing to stay down is more important than winning or losing. Sylvester Stallone in what would become his career-launching and defining role delivers a true, raw and passionate performance. Adrian is played to perfection by Talia Shire who was  really on a role in the 70s. You can see how much she and Rocky compliment one-another.  Burgess Meredith brings the character of Micky to life, a bitter trainer turned father figure to Rocky. Burt Young is solid as Paulie, and the charismatic adversary to Rocky, Apollo Creed is well-played by Carl Weathers. Bill Conti's iconic score helps to further engross you into the experience as well as inspire you. I absolutely love this film, and whether you're a boxing fan or not, I'm sure you will too.

The satisfying, classic boxing movie offers some decent messages.  Rocky is realistic about his goal.  He does not need to win.  He just needs to acquit himself with dignity, to show he is in the same league as the champion.  In order to achieve that goal he will risk giving everything he has, risk even the small pride of an unbroken nose.  He develops enough self-respect to risk public disgrace.  This is a big issue for teens, adolescence has been characterized as the years in which everything centers around the prayer, "God, don't let me be embarrassed today."  Rocky begins as someone afraid to give his best in case it is not good enough, and become someone who suspects that his best is enough to achieve his goals, and is willing to test himself to find out.

It's worth taking a look at Creed as well. Like here in the Aesop fable, he underestimates his opponent.  He is so sure of himself, and so busy working on the business side of the fight that he comes to the fight unprepared.

You can always rely on me for the controversial film takes. Here's another classic film that somehow I've only just gotten around to watching. I may get hate for this but it's just my opinion and immediate reaction after finishing watching this.

The first hour of this is very slow and felt like an overly bloated introduction to the world and characters before the main plot had even begun. It could have benefited from being 20 to 30 minutes shorter. Rocky is the only character throughout who I could feel any sort of connection with, and even then I wasn't particularly compelled due to Stallone's unconvincing performance.

The only part of this film I can say I genuinely enjoyed was that training montage; now one of the most iconic moments in cinema. Problem is that it's about an hour and a half into the film, with little positives beforehand. Even the ending climactic fight which is one of the more enjoyable aspects of the film felt silly and overly melodramatic.

I cannot really understand how this film is held in such high regard. I can see how people could enjoy enjoy this more than I have, but it is far from a great film. I found Raging Bull to be far superior in every regard.

Back in 2007, I traveled to the City of Brotherly Love, during which I paid a visit to the Philadelphia Museum of Art. I bring this up because back then I never saw the movie Rocky despite knowing where the iconic scene with the steps came from. Now, having finally seen the film, I can honestly say Rocky is one of my favorite sports movies of all time. Rocky Balboa (Sylvester Stallone) is an underdog Philly contender who's set up to fight Heavyweight champion Apollo Creed (Carl Weathers). Meanwhile, he hits up a date with shy pet shop owner Adrian (Talia Shire) and hires an old grouchy boxing manager Mickey (Burgess Meredith) to help him warm up for the Bicentennial Super Battle. What I loved so much about the movie, aside from Rocky's likable sweet-hearted persona, is that the majority of it centers on character interactions and relationships as well as the build-up to the boxing tournament. When it got to the match, I didn't expect Rocky to knock out Apollo first round nor Apollo winning the bout via split decision despite everyone, including Adrian, cheering for the Italian Stallion. That ending changes a whole new meaning in storytelling where the loser wins yet loses. Unfortunately, the sequels and the Creed films followed that conventional cliched ending where the protagonist wins the fight and loved ones. Maybe that's for the best because no matter how many sequels or spin-off movies get produced, we will always remember the first Rocky movie.

I can't say this often about a movie, but I wouldn't change a frame of the original Rocky. The film is perfect. From its inception to completion, it represents the hope of all underdogs that can bask in the dream that is Rocky. In 1976, Sylvester Stallone was an unknown actor and screenwriter, Burgess Meredith was washed up just like the role he plays in Mickey, Rocky's trainer and the only movie of merit directed by John Avildsen before this was Jack Lemmon's Oscar-winning performance in Save the Tiger. Sure, it's one of the most popular Cinderella stories of all time, but it's so good on its own right. The music, the cinematography, the casting, and direction are all top notch, and the screenplay—written by Stallone in three days—is one of the best of all time. All of the latter were not left unnoticed with the film receiving 10 Academy Award nominations in a strong Oscar year. It rightfully won best picture and made Stallone the superstar that he is today.
Best movie of all time.

Is Rocky the strangest film ever to win the Academy Award for Best Picture? As an underdog sports movie its Oscar appeal seems obvious, it remains highly acclaimed by many critics, and it was successful enough to both catapult its star to superstardom and to launch an entire movie franchise. But for all of this – and for all that its critics dismiss it as schmaltz – the most striking thing about the film is how odd it is.
Sylvester Stallone is often type-cast as an action hero due mostly to the subsequent Rambo franchise, a fact that he capitalised and poked fun at in The Expendables and its sequels. But at various times throughout his career he's proved that he can actually act and Rocky is the most prominent demonstration of this. Moreover, Rocky proved that he can also write: the script and Stallone's central performance are the two key factors that make the film as enjoyable as it is. It's interesting that in a story that is often predictable, it famously ends with Rocky failing to beat his opponent in the ring, but nevertheless gaining his respect and keeping his dignity. And of course, his real triumph at the end is when his girlfriend tells him that she loves him. 
But it is the actual character of Rocky that is the film's most striking feature. Stallone is effortlessly convincing as the somewhat dim-witted amateur boxer who works as a debt-collector but is too soft-hearted to be really good at it. Rocky is not a typical hero, nor is he a typical anti-hero: he's brooding, socially awkward and quietly eccentric. This is at its most obvious when he starts chatting up Adrianna "Adrian" Pennino – he sounds alternately shy and just weird, enthusing about his two pet turtles and deeply proud that his nose has never been broken. Theirs is one of the strangest and yet most convincing movie romances ever filmed. Talia Shire's Adrian is no more a conventional romantic lead than Rocky is: she's shy to the point that one of Rocky's acquaintances cruelly describes her as "retarded". Rocky's clumsy pursuit of her shows how well matched they are – his own confidence is skin deep, as their scenes together demonstrate and there are few movie dating scenes as frankly bizarre as the ice rink sequence.
It is this quirky characterisation that makes both Rocky and Adrian so endearing. Stallone fits this role perfectly, giving a naturalistic performance that includes a whole spectrum of emotions, his tender scenes with Adrian contrasting with his later fury at trainer Mickey and his obvious nervousness as the fight with Apollo Creed approaches. Stallone the writer's other characters are all quirky in their own way, from Adrian's brother Paulie to confident and egotistical showman Creed, and he pens dialogue for them that often sounds like the sort of realistically inconsequential and irrelevant small talk that real people engage in. 
Shire is as convincing as Adrian as Stallone is as Rocky, and strong support is provided by Carl Weathers as Creed and Burt Young as Paulie, although Burgess Meredith mostly just rasps a lot and looks grumpy as Mickey. During the climactic boxing match, Stallone and Creed both look genuinely battered and exhausted: it's a tribute to the acting and make-up, but nonetheless it isn't surprising that both incurred injuries whilst filming the scene. 
The climactic fight is very well choreographed. Carl Weathers plays up to the camera perfectly as Apollo Creed. It looks convincing – it's no wonder that both actors sustained injuries – with the pair looking realistically sweaty and exhausted. John G. Avildsen rarely crops up on people's lists of their favourite directors and his career can be fairly accurately described as variable, but he does a solid job here and delivers some scenes that have become iconic, most notably Rocky's training montage with its equally iconic "Gonna Fly Now" theme. Indeed, the soundtrack is sparingly used, so when it is deployed it packs – if you'll pardon the pun – a real punch. Cinematographer James Crabe's camerawork helps, since his reliance on medium and long shots helps to give the film the look of a documentary which adds an air of realism and the use of the Steadicam benefits the picture enormously.
I'm not sure that Rocky is a great film: it doesn't quite have the right mix of quality ingredients. But it's a lot less predictable than a summary of its plot might suggest, and a lot more interesting too. The credit for that is mostly due to the central performance and impressive script-writing of Sylvester Stallone and the overall result is a film that whilst not entirely deserving of its impressive reputation is nevertheless rather enjoyable.

The much beloved Rocky saga from Sly Stallone began with this film and it is indeed a great film, the best of the series in my opinion. What makes Rocky special is that it concentrates on characters, not sports. It would be disingenuous to say that the climactic boxing match is unimportant - it is, after all the movie's centerpiece - but that's not all Stallone's movie is about. There are only two fights - one at the beginning and one at the end. In between, every screen moment is used to develop Rocky as a person. He is not traditional hero material - he's crude, stupid, boorish, and has limited aspirations. Nevertheless, there's something likable about the guy, and it has its root in the gentle, caring way he treats Adrian. And it's this relationship that's the key to making Rocky's ending triumphant. He may lose the fight, but he gains so much more. This is movie magic at its finest.

Rocky is way more than just a sports movie. I've seen people write Rocky off as a by the numbers sports movie with no quality or intelligence to be found, but it is much more. Every second of screen time you can feel the heart put into this movie from the amazing behind the scene story of Sylvester Stallone making Rocky to the love of Philidelphia poured in. If heart isn't enough for you, have no fear because Rocky is chocked full of outstanding and memorable characters. Almost every single character in this movie will draw you in and make you root for them from Sylvester Stallone's humble and lovable Rocky Balboa to Carl Weathers's charismatic and charming portrayal of Apollo Creed. Rocky features some of the most realistic and well-written characters in recent cinematic history. The movie starts off a bit slow but when it really starts, there's no stopping it with iconic training montages and an emotional climax of a final fight all of which resulted in Rocky being they underdog movie. If you like stories based on well-written and likable characters with iconic cinematic moments, Rocky is the movie for you, give it the chance it deserves.

And it's not just a sport flick, the script is very well written and shows us the hypocrisy of the American Dream and the reality of the blue-collar society. And that last fight at the end was pretty suspenseful. Overall, Rocky is a good classic for sure. Recommended!!

This is a big, warm crowd-pleaser with a surprisingly charming lead character and a beautiful love story at the center of it's narrative. I had seen this twice in full previously and I've witnessed snippets of it several times whether on TV or at a recreation center but re-watching it I was able to appreciate just how good Talia Shire is as Adrian and yes, be inspired in a very clichÃ (C) fashion. If you have a father born some time in the last 60 years then you will almost have definitely seen this film but even if you're a teenage girl with little to no interest in sports, like myself, it's still a very enjoyable film to watch.

Rocky Balboa, Sylvester Stallone, is an Italian-American man working in Philadelphia as a Mafia enforcer while chasing dreams of being a heavyweight boxer. His manager and trainer is Paulie Pennino who pushes him to make more public appearances and hype up his fights more. Rocky also romantically pursues Paulie's sister Adrian, Talia Shire, as he prepares to fight the fearsome Apollo Creed in a match that may or may not be fixed. Rocky begins to doubt himself as the fight approaches but encouragement from those around him cause him to believe in himself.

The most interesting part of the film was, to me, the love story as we see an unintelligent but sweet oaf fall in love with the shy, bookish young woman. Their first date, on which she ice skates around an empty rink whilst he runs along side her and tells her about boxing, contains better dialogue than you would expect from a sports film and the chemistry between Stallone and Shire is so great that this somewhat unbelievable love story feels genuine. Yes, their â~love' scene does seem a little non-consensual in today's #metoo era but I believe that Adrian does show consent and we see two people grow more comfortable with themselves in a healthy and loving relationship. Adrian does begin to dress more like a 1970s model towards the end of the film but Shire retains her sensible, motherly attitude in how she approaches the character and the final scene in which they embrace gets my tear ducts flowing.

Rocky's relationship to his community is another touch that makes this film special as the film makes an effort to display what makes Philadelphia special as a city. The iconic scene in which Rocky runs all the way up the steps to the town hall and throws his fists up in the air can still create a real rush of excitement in any viewer and as we see a wide shot overlooking Philadelphia we understand why Rocky is proud to be from this city. Seeing him punch meat on local television is funny but it also gives you the sense that people in this city really do care about the plight of this uneducated boxer because they can identify with him. The only other films I really associate with Philadelphia are those of M. Night Shyamalan and those quickly decreased in quality.

Stallone's central performance isn't what you would call great acting as he appears to be playing a semi-fictitious version of himself but he injects the character with a gentle giant persona that makes it hard not to root for him. All of the supporting players are great as we get a lot of unexpectedly sweet tough men and as previously mentioned Shire is worth the price of admission alone. The film is more than the sum of it's parts in this way in that most of the acting isn't on the level of Henry Fonda, the writing is pretty basic and the film doesn't look exceptional and yet it's a truly great film.

This is a film that can be watched at any time, in any place with or without company. It doesn't require a huge amount of engagement or analysis to be enjoyable and will probably tug at the heartstrings of even the most cynical audience member.

Considering this as a Best Picture winner however is more difficult as it was up against the hugely influential classics Taxi Driver (1976) and Network (1976) both of which wrestle with weightier themes and are widely considered two of the best films of the 1970s. I would have awarded Taxi Driver because it is a great film that's darker and more interesting than Rocky and rewarding Scorsese for one of his best films would mean that Gangs of New York (2002) didn't earn a Best Picture nomination.

Rocky has become a part of popular culture for so many years its hard to look at the first film as a standalone low budget entry in the boxing genre. This is a great film and put the writer and main lead Sylvester Stallone into the stratosphere of Hollywood. Considering what the Rocky series became - popcorn action films with little heart, less intelligence, and a lot of testosterone - it's a somewhat refreshing experience to go back and re-connect with the original, which offers a lot more substance than the sequels. Rocky is not a flawless motion picture, but it is a feel-good classic, and well worth another look. The basic storyline has been done to death over the years; this is still one of the most effective and successful applications of the formula.

"Rocky", released in 1976, follows underdog Rocky Balboa as he sets out to fight a heavy-weight champion. The film made me root for Rocky and made me feel that you can achieve your dreams, even as an underdog and fits into the dramatic genre that way. As professional work, I don't feel that there is anything that could or should have been done differently with the film. Somehow, I never knew that this film was written by Sylvester Stallone and enjoyed the story. I particularly liked the scene where Rocky and Adrian are on their first date. Rocky is trying so hard to make conversation with her and relate to her that he shows her his dislocated finger. I laughed out loud watching that scene! Directed by John G. Avildsen, I appreciated that he chose to use a lot of shots where the characters favor one side of frame. To me it clues us into moments of isolation that the character is experiencing. This is evident in the scene where Rocky and Paulie are arguing in the hallway over Rocky dating Adrian. Edited by Scott Conrad and Richard Haley, my favorite edit was when the scene was cutting between the interview with Rocky and following his training methods to Apollo watching Rocky's interview to men taking bets on rocky. It added so much to the story to have insight into each person's perspective on the match and see what's at stake. Acting-wise, I particularly enjoyed Talia Shire's performance as Adrian. My favorite scene of hers was when Rocky first comes to see her for dinner with Paulie. Adrian comes out of the kitchen, sees Rocky, and turns right back into the kitchen in one fluid motion. It immediately clues us into her feeling bashful without her having to say anything. In regard to cinematography, I enjoyed the scene where Rocky and Apollo have a TV interview. James Crabe captured the aesthetics of how interviews on TV looked then and it created a great contrast for the rest of the scenes in the film. One of my favorite examples of sound design was when Rocky and Adrian say good night to each other, and you can hear a train slowly getting closer to where they are in the background. The trains are a huge part of the city and that touch brings us as an audience even deeper into the story. Overall, I think the production value is of great quality considering the period that the film was shot in, as well as the minimal budget it was shot with. You can tell that the shots of Rocky running through the streets of Philadelphia were shot separately from the rest of the film (they were done guerilla style) as the production value isn't as high as the other shots. The guerrilla shots are much grittier.

Rocky is pneumatalily known as a great classic. It stars Sylvester Stallone who plays the underdog Rocky who gets a chance to fight Apollo Creed in the ring for a shot at the title. Sylvester Stallone doesn't only give an outstanding performance (which got him an Oscar nominee) he even was able to write a script which was very good. Despite Rocky's lines getting quite repetitive at times. This film is actually loosely based of a true story, about the fight between Muhammad Ali and Chuck Wepner. Here is the story about Sylvester Stallone's inspiration. At a theater in Los Angeles, struggling actor Sylvester Stallone watched the Ali-Wepner fight and promptly went home and banged out the script for a little movie called "Rocky.". It wasn't based on a true story -- not directly. But it was inspired by and borrowed heavily from a true story.

I do not know who done the boxing choreography in this, but who ever did, done a brilliant job. Sylvester Stallone done the boxing choreography in the third one, so I am not sure if he done the first. I got one problem with this movie and that is the romantic plot between Rocky and Adrian (played by Talia Shire). The problem with the romantic side of the film is that you focus more on what is happening with Rocky's love life, other than you worrying about Rocky training for his fight. Every single actor went there hardest into this film and gave the best performance out of the five in the franchise.

 The training sequence in the final is the most memorable training sequence in the entire Rocky franchises because all the others are basically copies of the first but with a twist. The final fight scene with Rocky and Creed was the only non predictable final fight in the saga because as this is the first and if there was a sequel confirmed at the time, you would think that he would win. That is what the final is jaw dropping excitement, which will always keep you on the edge of your seat wondering what will happen next. 

So overall Rocky is jaw dropping excitement. I would go as far as to call this a classic alongside (Jaws, Back to the Future, E. T, Jurassic Park etc.) But isn't as good as them. It is definitely the best one in the saga because it is a classic and the others tend to get same old, same old.

This is my third time seeing Rocky and I’ve never really liked it as much as I really wanted to... until now. I have somewhat of a bias on this one, but I don’t necessarily think it will affect my review. Rocky is my girlfriend’s favorite movie of all time and I’ve had several conversations where I confess that I think the film’s just... fine. However, I’ve owned the whole series for a couple years now and I’d never seen the other movies. So with Creed II coming out next week, I’m gonna binge my way to the finish. So expect a lot more Rocky reviews soon. What made this experience different is instead of just watching the movie again, I listened to the commentary track by Sylvester Stallone. That is what made this film a great experience. Stallone explained the little things that I’d never really considered. It’s so obvious that he poured so much into this film. His indepth analysis is very engaging and really brings out the true character of Rocky and Adrian. I still think the cinematography is very well done (those steadicam shots are gorgeous) and the iconic shots at the Philadelphia Art Museum are still so magical. The sound design is very well done as well as the editing. The acting from Talia Shire is really great, Stallone is alright but his weakness is in the writing. Burt Young, who’s character is annoying as hell, gives a solid performance and his subtle facial expressions explain everything he wants to say. Carl Weathers absolutely deserves a shout out for his work in the film. Despite his little screen time, his presence is felt throughout. My biggest issue is mainly the writing. Rocky’s dialogue is so dumb and unintelligible. Like, I get that’s his character but it’s difficult to cheer for a creepy dumbass. I still find the scene in Rocky’s apartment where he flirts with Adrien cringey and creepy as hell. He’s dull and boring and the only reason I really liked him this time around was because Stallone explained his decisions and thoughts. Overall, I still don’t really love Rocky. However, I definitely appreciate it a lot more, enough to give it a 4 star review (AKA a certified good movie in my book). Stallone’s passion is eminent, even if the writing isn’t always on point. The cinematography is fantastic and revolutionary, the fight scenes are electric and satisfying. I can’t wait to watch the rets of the series. 8.0/10

Rocky took a well-worn story and redefined it by delving deep into the characters.
 
Rocky's character arc is so familiar that everyone, even who don't watch many movies, knows every single detail about it. But the movie adds a simple twist, yet a very effective one, in the character's motivations.

But it didn't stop here, as the movie keeps raising the stakes by making an advantage of all the developments that have been given to all the characters.

The movie could have easily used the ups and downs of Rocky to evoke our feelings. Instead, the movie succeeded to be very moving by taking advantage of the very new twist that has been added to Balboa's motivations. The result is an underdog heroic character that is by no means clichéd. And Stallone shines in this movie and gave his best performance in his career. There are some moments when Rocky's confidence has been shaken a little bit and the hero starts to tell the message of the story and these moments somewhat worked, and they could have never worked without Sylvester Stallone's superb acting.

I said that Rocky takes advantage of the developments of all its characters. Yes, all its characters!

The character of Adrian, for instance, has some realistic and genuine details that make the romance between her and Rocky works very well, although the relationship proceeds so fast. Talia Shire performance made Adrian even more realistic,unique and very compelling character.

Paulie is another great character that made the movie even more poignant as it gave some depth for Rocky too.

What I didn't like so much is Apollo Creed. In contrast to the rest of the characters, he is nothing but the stereotypical undefeated Champion. Also, all decisions he made exposed the movie's clichéd story. With that being said, his scenes are masterfully directed and he has a very catchy style.  

The final fight scene is maybe the most realistic fight scene has been shot at that time. And those who think it's not, please watch a boxing match and you'll find that boxing punches make sounds different from the comic book punches sounds that are still used in movies today.

Nevermind that Rocky is a nice/honest person with a passion for animals, yet maintains an unscrupulous job out of unapparent necessity. - Or that his bloodthirsty Loan Shark boss actually seems like a pretty swell guy........Or that his first date with Adrian looked like highlights from a #Metoo incident. It's not about any of that. It's about a blue collar American finding an opportunity. A true underdog story - One that we can all appreciate.

Rocky, a story of a poor boxer that doesn't have much gets a shot at the world heavyweight title against the world champion Apollo Creed. Rocky Balboa starts the movie working as a debt collector in run down Philadelphia, who's trying to make it big time in the boxing arena. Struggling to do so, his coaches, friends and employees fail to give him the time of day. When Apollo Creed, Heavyweight Champion of the World, comes to Rocky looking for a chance to turn a "nobody" into a "somebody". The match is suppose to be an easy fight for the champ, but the Rocky "The Italian Stallion" Balboa takes this fight as his only shot to make it big time, and gives Apollo a run for his money. This storyline is one reason that Rocky is considered one the the greatest movies on the 1970's and I believe that it is one of the greatest ever. This movie is an all time great because of the amazing storyline and the emotional connection you feel towards the characters, the incredibly small budget they had to produce this movie and all of the awards that Rocky has won.
	The story of a poor man, who becomes rich and gets the the girl, might sound cliche but it feels far from it due of the emotional connection that pulls the audience in. In the review of rocky by Roger Ebert, a creditable critic, says the reason that this movie is great is because the audience feel connected (Ebert,1976). A movie with a good storyline and a bad connection with the audience is a bad movie, a movie that connects to the audience but has a bad storyline is also a bad movie, Rocky has an amazing storyline and the audience feels to be apart of the story. Roger Ebert also states that movies from the 70's lacked that emotional side, so rocky sort of came during a "emotional drought". The movie audience loved this movie when it came out because they felt something that the haven't felt in a while, a love for the characters. This emotional side of the movie helps put rocky on the all time great list because people remember how they felt watching this movie and the feel to be apart of the movie. 
	Rocky is one of the most successful movies of all time with a cumulative world wide gross of  over two-hundred twenty-five million dollars. To put that into perspective The Terminator, a movie made around the same time as rocky, and still considered a successful movie made forty million in sales. A reason that Rocky's two-hundred twenty-five million dollars in sales is so impressive is because of their budget on the movie. Rocky was produced with less than a million dollars. Terminator was produced with over six million dollars. The producers of Rocky had to take a mortgage on their homes to come up with money to produce this movie. Rocky also didn't have any really big and famous actors in the movie at the time, so because of that they didn't have to pay them too much money. Just like the movie, these actors were looking for their chance to make it big time and this movie was their chance to make it. They all put everything they had into this movie and it payed off. This movie proves that it doesn't need a lot of money to make a successful movie.
	Rocky has won several awards and is one of the winningest movies of all time. It has won an Academy Award for Best Picture, Academy Award for Best Director, Academy Award for Best Film Editing, David di Donatello for Best Foreign Actor, Directors Guild of America for Outstanding Directing, and a Japan Academy Prize for Outstanding Foreign Language Film (IMDB,2018). This movie won are was nominated for most of the awards in 1977.  These awards back up the statement that Rocky is one of the greatest film ever created.
	Many people view this as just another fighting movie and that this one is just falls in line behind other great boxing movies. This movie is another boxing movie but it is responsible for the birth of the four other Rockys and the new boxing movie creed.
In conclusion in a time when not many great emotional attaching movies were out Rocky was produced. The movie didn't need a ton of money and amazing CGI effects to make it great. The movie has a great storyline and some actors and producers that want a shot at making it big time. It won several awards and was one of the best movies of the decade. But Rocky remains one of the greatest movies of all time because of the amazing storyline and the emotional connection you feel towards the characters, the incredibly small budget they had to produce this movie and all of the awards that Rocky has won.

John G. Avildsen's now classic boxing melodrama is without doubt the greatest underdog story in cinematic history. It concerns a 30 year old, two-bit club fighter from Philadelphia named Rocky Balboa, played brilliantly and with true conviction by Sylvester Stallone in a breakout performance that earned him a richly deserved Academy Award nomination for Best Actor. Rocky gets a supremely rare "million-to-one shot" for fame in a championship bout against the Heavyweight Champion of the World, Apollo Creed, played terrifically by Carl Weathers. It is Apollo who dreams up this publicity stunt to give a nobody a title shot during the bicentennial celebration of America. No one takes Rocky serious, but he trains hard with his old trainer Mickey Goldmill, played sensationally by the late great veteran character actor Burgess Meredith in memorable turn that earned him an Academy Award nomination for Best Supporting Actor. Rocky will gain his self-respect and prove to everyone that he can go the distance. The lovely Talia Shire received an Academy Award nomination for Best Actress for her marvelous performance as Adrian, the painfully shy pet store worker who falls in love with Rocky, and Burt Young received an Academy Award nomination for Best Supporting Actor for his superlative performance as Adrian's older brother Pauline who is a pain-in-the-ass drunkard. Skillful Academy Award winning direction by Avildsen, with a compelling Academy Award nominated original screenplay by Stallone, and an evocative Academy Award nominated score by Bill Conti. A triumphant film that is so inspiring and moving, it perfectly demonstrates the strength of the human spirit to overcome all odds. This low-budget cinematic gem became a surprise mega-hit box office sensation at the time of it's release and was followed by 5 sequels and a 2015 spin-off hit sequel "Creed." Winner of 3 Academy Awards including Best Picture. Highly recommended.

There's a moment in Rocky where Carl Weathers (evoking Muhammad Ali as the sharp tongued champ Apollo Creed), hatches a plan for his next main event fight in the absence of any high profile opponents. He'll fight an unknown, a random local contender, and it'll work. It'll work because, as Apollo says "I'm sentimental, and a lot of other people in this country are just as sentimental." The scene plays like an admission from writer Stallone and director Avildsen. Rocky is here to prey on our sentimentalities. It's completely predictable, hopelessly clichéd and glaringly transparent in its schmaltzy coaxing of our sympathies. You'd be forgiven for thinking of Rocky as On the Waterfront's parallel universe, in which Terry was able to break away from his seedy world just long enough to become a contender. What Sylvester Stallone and John G. Avildsen offer us is by no means anything new, yet for all its missing subtleties, it's impossible to deny that Rocky works. 

Why is this? It's because it speaks to a fantasy that's innate in all of us. It's a film which gives us the right moment, and the right characters, in which that story we all wish to lose ourselves in can be realised. How easy is it to place yourself in Rocky's shoes? How fun to release your cynicisms and live those childhood fancies if only for a short while? 

And we get the perfect  vicarious underdog in Stallone's title character. His is a fantastically charming performance. As well as Terry Malloy, there are also traces of Herman Munster in Stallone's benign but droopy features, and Rupert Pupkin in his clumsy talkativeness and lame humour. 

Rocky would like to think of himself as an older brother to those dwelling in Philadelphia's chilled streets. He spouts his advice and tries to help, but we know he's really trying to convince himself he's something more than a two-bit debt collector working the docks. He thinks of himself as a bum, as do most people, and he fights nobodies for little money. Boxing is his real passion. 

In other hands the plight of Rocky Balboa could have been an awfully ham-fisted one, but Stallone allows us to fall in love with his character. We want Rocky to succeed, to prove everyone wrong and realise his self worth; when we see Rocky raise his arms in fantasy atop of those famed stairs, there's little doubt as to how affected we've been by his story. 

Rocky gets his chance to become something more when Creed selects him as the local contender who gets a shot. Rocky is gifted an opportunity to be "somebody" (as Brando would say) by stepping in the ring with the champion, but this isn't where the true drama lays. What's surprising about the film is how little of it is about boxing.

Most impressive about Stallone's writing and Alvidsen's direction is how devoted they are to their characters, letting them materialise into much more than the mere archetypes they so easily could have been. It's the attention they pay to their characters that allows the championship fight to be so dramatic, to become something much more than a punch-up for a belt. 

Talia Shire plays Adrian, the love interest of Rocky, a painfully shy pet store clerk who he drops in on like clockwork to crack "dad" jokes and babble to. Their story is the true heart of Rocky, and it's one of genuine romance, the two finding a much needed appreciation for themselves in their affection for each other. Burt Young plays her belligerent, heavy drinking brother Paulie, a friend of Rocky's and a volatile schlub who's at once envious of Rock's new success, and latches to it like a determined leach. Burgess Meredith plays the trainer at Rocky's gym, the irritable, gravel voiced Mick who resents Rocky for never fulfilling his potential. He senses a chance for Rocky to finally redeem himself, but It's also an opportunity for his own underachieving self to find redemption. In the film's most downbeat moment, Mick grovels to Rocky, begging for the chance to train and manage him, despite so many years of browbeating. It's a harrowing moment of vulnerability, and the film is drip fed moments just like it, moments which bring our sympathies to life for the characters.

Rocky's transparency is a problem. It swings sentimentality around like a flail and it treads narrative ground that has been stomped to the crust, its obviousness in doing so always threatening to take us out of the moment. But Apollo's right. We are sentimental, we love being sentimental, and Rocky has enough passion and enough heart to make such sentimentality warranted.

What most people don't realize is that Rocky isn't so much of a boxing movie as it is a love story. Well, that's what I got from it, anyway. The boxing is a big part of it, but we don't even get to the real meat of that story until about an hour in. And without even realizing it, we're getting a whole lot of character depth during the first half of the film. 

Forget the creepy way that Rocky forces Adrian to give him that first kiss. The story as a whole is sweet. She's a true diamond in the rough. It's almost not even believable at first, but the two have so much chemistry that it works. 

But like most of the movie, their relationship is without much conflict. Rocky doesn't overcome any crazy obstacles. He's a lazy boxer who hasn't made anything of his life, and when some freak opportunity presents itself, he finally works hard and gets what he wants. There isn't anything really standing in his way. Perhaps if they threw some conflict in there it may come off as contrived, but how it is now, it seems too easy. Maybe that's the point. I don't know.

Undefeated heavyweight champion, Apollo Creed (Carl Weathers) needs a new opponent for the title fight after his current one drops out. But he wants this new competitor to be a no name amateur, so that the public will get into the underdog story. 

And it's a good underdog story at that. You root for Rocky undeniably. But there could just be a little more in terms of a struggle. The biggest risk he takes is handed to him. And what does he have to lose, anyway?

Much of the film is dated with the fake punches and the already antiquated dialogue. There are points where the patter is so rhythmic that it sounds like it's from the '40s or '50s. It's a slow moving film, and some scenes just drag on for way too long. It helps add to the character development, but it does a number on our attention span. 

Then there's predictability. The end result is telegraphed from a mile away. We can guess what's going to happen for most of the film. And we are usually proven right--another side effect of there not being any unexpected drama. 

Nowadays, we have a quixotical view of Rocky, the all-American hero. Even the Academy was lost in its gaze with this film winning Best Picture back in 1977. But sadly, it's not as good as we want it to be. But that's not to say it's not good. It's still a cool underdog story, albeit not paying off as well as its predictability wants it to. However, corniness aside, this film set the pace for countless stories that came after it. And most of all, it has a lot of heart. You can't knock it for that.

Arguably the greatest sports movie of all time.  So this is about a small time boxer named Rocky Balboa (Sylvester Stallone).  He doesn't have a whole lot going on for him, but he gets by.  One day, the chance to fight the heavyweight champion, Apollo Creed (Carl Weathers), falls in his lap, and he must start training immediately for this momentous occasion.  I went a very long time without watching this movie.  Not because I had any bias against it, it was just a film that I never took the time to sit down and watch.  As far as popularity goes, I do think this was my biggest blind spot in film, and people have given me a hard time on a number of different occasions for not having seen this.  With the release of Creed, I couldn't think of a better time to rectify this, and what do you know, it really is the greatest boxing movie ever made.  I don't usually go for boxing movies and that is entirely because so many of them follow the same exact template.  With movies like Southpaw or The Fighter, you know exactly what you're going to get, which is a story that goes a little something like this: an unlikely protagonist rises up and overcomes struggles and hardship to bring their personal life around through their sport and craft.  There, I just described almost every film in an entire genre.  The thing is that they all got it from Rocky, as it is the original and still remains the best.  Not even just boxing movies lift from Rocky, sport movies in general do; we wouldn't have one of my favorite films in The Wrestler if we didn't have Rocky.  I love less-than-intelligent protagonists when they are earnest, and this has one of the best examples out there; you can see all of the emotions right there on his sleeve, and Stallone play it masterfully.  The training montage to this is amazing; I've seen it by itself on its own, but in the actual context of the film, it is even better.  That music is like no other, and when the brass section starts playing, it is like instant energy flows into your body as soon as you hear it.  It is more than just a boxing movie, and the thought did cross my mind: for a boxing movie, there's really not all that much boxing.  You have a fight at the beginning and the climactic fight at the end, and that's really about it.  The middle is almost entirely drama and training, and that is the meat of the story.  You get a great feel of all of the characters so you can really rally behind them and root for them, and you also get a really good feel of Philadelphia as a city.  I am still of the mindset that once you've seen one boxing movie, you've seen them all, but this is the one that did it best.
It's too simplistic and drawn out, but rocky has a gritty quality that is made all the more effect by Stallone's masterful performance and chemistry with the other characters.

Predictable in the fact that filmgoers will always root for the underdog if they love that underdog, Rocky stands heads and shoulders above all of the boxing tales that try replicating its singular charm...including, ironically, its own sequels. Remarkable not for its originality but for making a Capra-esque human drama that inspires rather patronizes, Rocky isn't the first underdog sports story but it does define the genre from here on-in. Indeed, if it had premiered 30 years earlier, this film very well might have been titled It's a Wonderful Life, You Bum.

In this PG-rated sports drama, a small-time Philadelphia boxer (Stallone) gets a supremely rare chance to fight the heavy-weight champion, Apollo Creed (Carl Weathers), in a bout in which he strives to go the distance for his self-respect. 

Sylvester Stallone's script and performance, ahem, punch up pure character out of a caricature and provide a heart-warming tale that impossibly sports a blue collar Can-Do human spirit that seems unbeatable, even in a very cynical age. Arriving in a decade populated with hard-edged terminally pessimistic dramas such as The French Connection, Serpico, Network, All the President's Men, Taxi Driver, and Apocalypse Now!, Rocky's optimism in presenting the simple unshakable drive of an everyman's champion makes it an underdog of a different sort. The fact that it won the Oscar for Best Picture and became a blockbuster stands testament to the fact that filmgoers responded to it even if the material stands a slight step below quality-wise. Still, director John G. Avildsen's guiding hand gives film history one of the most indelible scenes of all time when our challenger reminds us what's more important than winning by screaming out to find his true love amid the maddening crowd: "Adrian!!!" 

Bottom line: Right Hook of God

Everyone loves a good underdog story. When someone who is at the bottom, rises up and becomes what they are meant to be and proves everyone who doubted them wrong in the process. Rocky is not just a great movie, but for someone like myself who has lived in Philadelphia his entire life, as silly as it sounds, it is more than a movie. Rocky defines my city and embodies everything about the city of Philadelphia. Sure, Philly is a major city but is it kind of stuck in the shadow of New York and Boston. Maybe you have to be from my town, but seeing Rocky Balboa run through the city and the Italian market during his training scenes makes the hair on my arms stand straight up. Although it is a fictional character, it gives me a sense of pride that Rocky takes place in my city. Which is an underdog city to begin with. Ok, I know they probably have made too many sequels in the Rocky franchise and it got really silly with Rocky 5, but this is one of the best movies of all time. Not just the best sports movie of all time, but of any genre. A small low budget project that was shot in a few weeks in Philadelphia, and it won Best Picture at the Oscars. Talk about a true underdog right there. Sometimes music it good in a movie and sometimes it literally defines a movie. The latter is the case here. Everyone and I mean everyone knows the Rocky theme. There is no way when you hear that music that you don't automatically think of Rocky Balboa running up the Philadelphia Art Museum steps
I'd give it a 10 if I could. Best movie in history.

Rocky's release in 1976 took audiences into the journey of a down-on-his-luck boxer getting his chance at the big league against the famous: Apollo Creed. At the time, it won 3 Academy Awards and is a home stable to Americans everywhere since. However, does it still hold up after all these years? Yes, yes it does. While it's easy to point out it's fairly predictable story, lacking antagonist, and also lacking in grip in its finale, the title character's heartwarming and terrific performance, great soundtrack (the most iconic: Gonna Fly Now,) inspiring tone and message, well developed and heartwarming romance, and superb writing and acting from Sylvester Stallone and direction from John Avildsen make this a film that while maybe had a unbalanced trilogy of films to follow on the emotional and inspiring tone of this film, say for maybe the final film, this reminds us of the Italian Stallion man that gave audiences a broken down and relatable character to cheer for all the way to the end.

The rest of the cast is great, the direction is amazing, and the score is so iconic that it is become a being of its own. This is a classic and a must see for fans of dramas, sports films, and underdog stories.

I don't even know how to start a review for Rocky. It's one of those rarities that always leaves me genuinely feeling something when it's over, no matter how many times I see it. I saw Rocky for the first time when I was around seven years old. Surprisingly, I wasn't bored. Even then, I knew it was something special. I grew up with these films and there was just something about them that just had so much heart, especially the first one. Sylvester Stallone wrote this screenplay in just three days which is pretty amazing. He wanted desperately to play the title character and fought for it. Thankfully, he did and if he didn't, not only would the movie not be the same but it would not have been nearly as successful, let alone forerun six sequels. Stallone as Rocky Balboa is one of the most special portrayals in cinematic history. Throughout the movies, he creates such a character that makes me feel like I know him. From the way all the characters are written, you feel like you get to know them. What helps is that the whole cast really do become their characters. Even though "Taxi Driver" and "Network" are probably more talked about in film classes, "Rocky" absolutely deserved to win Best Picture in 1977. It also has such an excellent message. It's not necessarily about winning, it's about going the distance with the best. If Rocky could go the distance, he feels like he's already won in a way and he is better than what people think of him.

Regarded as one of the original, and certainly most celebrated, sports biopics, Rocky tugged its audience's heartstrings and prized out every last one of their tears. Watching it today, I can understand why people fell for it so badly, but I can't really see why it's thought of as a traditionally 'great' movie. It's takes a long time to get going, has a very sluggish pace and is very often bogged down by scenes of wallowing in pity and self-doubt. These are very familiar to anyone who's seen a modern sports bio, and back then they obviously weren't as well-worn as they are now, but the entire film still comes off as entirely predictable. Rocky is the stereotypical underdog, he's going to struggle, he's going to have people doubt him and tell him he'll ever make it, he's going to get angry and alienate those close to him but in the end he's going to win everyone's respect.  I do like the twist at the end, but aside from that the whole film is by-the-numbers. Rocky starts out a very likable character, full of pep and always cracking jokes despite his destitution, but after a while he becomes the typical downbeat, I'll-never-make-it-so-why-should-I-even-try guy, and it sucks the life out of what could have been a much more entertaining film.

Rocky (Sylvester Stallone, who also wrote the screenplay) is an amateur boxer who supports himself by working on the docks and debasing himself as collection muscle for a local loan shark. He gets an unexpected shot at greatness when the heavyweight champ (Carl Weathers) randomly chooses him for a fight as part of a promotional gimmick. Depending on your tastes, Rocky is a heartening underdog fable or a sentimental fountain of sports cliches that inexplicably won the Oscar for Best Picture. I found myself enjoying this film thanks to Stallone's grounded performance and the story's insistence on keeping things character-driven. The sequels, which get exponentially more cartoonish with each further installment, often lack either of these components.

"Rocky" is the quintessential boxing film, the blue print for all the Rocky rip-offs and sequels that would follow over the next 4 decades. And the film still holds up today, despite the overuse of its tropes, and becomes a very enjoyable uplifting film.

The story follows amateur struggling boxer Rocky Balboa, who is contemplating retirement due to the lack of opportunities. However, when heavyweight champion Apollo Creed pulls his name out of a hat and offers to fight him in a showcase event, Rocky finds himself pushing further than he ever had before, while dating his best friend's sister.

Sylvester Stallone, who also wrote the screenplay, stars in the title role, in what would become his breakout performance in Hollywood. Alongside him are Talia Shire, Burt Young, Carl Weathers and Burgess Meredith, all putting in solid performances - particularly Weathers as the flamboyant and arrogant Apollo Creed.

Despite the surprise ending, this film is ultimately an uplifting feel-good movie - something modern boxing/fighting films seem to lack in their dark and gritty tones. The comedy in this film is primitive in nature, but wonderfully executed anyway, and the relationships and characters are suitably fleshed out.

This is a classic film, and remains strong to this day. A must-have addition for any film buff. 9/10

Its easy to forget that Rocky won the best picture in 1975 - which initially was kind of surprising to me.  Movies about underdog athletes don't usually resonate with Oscar voters.  But watching Rocky this time around I realized something - this isn't a sports movie.  This is a movie about a self proclaimed 'nobody' finding love.  Rocky before it is anything else is a love story.  Sure there is the boxing, Apollo Creed, the emotional music and Mickey the trainer all of the stuff that makes for a good sports movie.  But this movie is about Rocky and Adrienne - two of the least likely lovers in all of Hollywood.  And that's what makes this movie Oscar worthy.  There are nuances in this movie that you just don't always see in other places.  For example when Mickey offers to manage Rocky.  Mickey is desperate to bring meaning to his own life, Rocky is angry that he's been overlooked for so many years; angry that Mickey only wants to be a part of his life now that he's fighting a big fight.  But there's that moment of quiet reconciliation when Rocky chases Mickey into the street - a reconciliation between two 'nobodies.'  I loved that scene and that's why its hard not to love Rocky.  He gives voice to the "nobody" in all of us - and reminds us that we are indeed a somebody.

It's hard to believe that there was a time where Sylvester Stallone was thought to be the new Marlon Brando, where he was an Academy Award nominated actor and writer and that he managed to defeat Taxi Driver in the "Best Film" category in 1976! I am talking about the beloved classic: "Rocky".
The year is 1975; heavyweight champion Apollo Creed is preparing to defend his title in the world heavyweight championship in Philadelphia, but his opponent drops out because of an injury. With no professional boxer willing to accept because of the short time they would have for training, Apollo decides to give a local underdog a shot at the title. Based only in his nickname "The Italian Stallion", Apollo chooses the unknown boxer Rocky Balboa.
The first installment of the franchise is not what you would expect from a Rocky film nowadays, (lots of training montages and a long but well choreographed boxing match at the end resulting in a victory for Rocky) I even argue that this is not a sport film, this is well executed and engaging drama. It has a well told and relatable story; a variety of characters that you care for, acting that is pretty good with Sylvester Stallone giving the best performance of his career, a theme that still has the same power than in 1976, a memorable score, an iconic ending, great directing and the most important; it has a lot of heart that will get some sentiments out of you. This is not a sport film that is all about the underdog winning the match; it's deeper and smarter than that, it talks about the big opportunities that you get in life and that alone makes you care about the path that Rocky will take. It is not a masterpiece but still is one of the greatest films of the 70s. My big complain is that there are not enough of certain characters and they deserved to have more screen time.
Of course it has people saying that it is overrated, but it really isn't. If you enjoy sport films, you need to be warned that this is drama. Undeniably the best of the franchise and arguably the best "sport" film ever made.

Carl Weathers is great as Apollo Creed and he's extremely likeable. The direction, writing and cinematography are all fantastic. The music is amazing. The main theme is one of the best pieces of music ever. The training montage is great. The end boxing match is brilliant. This is a fantastic film and while it drags a bit in places it's brilliant. A
